desc.s1: Since January, I have been working as a Back-end Engineer and I am proud to say that I am part of Upstream, a division of Wiener Stadwerke group. Our primary focus is developing a white-label app that aims to enhance public transportation in urban areas. The app is designed to work across several cities in the DACH region, including Vienna, and provide mobility information and services for various transport solutions.
desc.s2: As a Back-end Engineer, my core responsibilities include back-end development, software testing, and DevOps. Tools like Kubernetes, Jira, Harbor, Jenkins, SonarQube, Zephyr, WSL, Postman, Docker, etc. I use daily. I am constantly learning and expanding my practical skills while working in an agile team.

java.desc: Most of the work I do is reactive java.

spring.desc: For every microservice we use SpringBoot.

kubernetes.desc: Kubernetes, K9s, Minikube and others I use daily.

bitbucket.desc: For version control we use BitBucket.

coins.name: IEEE International Conference on Omni-layer Intelligent systems

desc.s1: From my bachelor thesis, I refined my project for COINS 2023, where I was honored as a finalist. In Berlin, I presented the paper, titled:
desc.s2: ''Performance Comparison of Post-Quantum Signature Algorithms Through An Android Email Application Plug-in.''
desc.s3: It was a rewarding opportunity to share insights into this emerging field, as the PQC algorithms were not yet implemented into an Android application yet.

java.desc: The open source E-Mail client K-9 Mail is written in Java & Kotlin.

kotlin.desc: The open source E-Mail client K-9 Mail is written in Java & Kotlin.

git.desc: The project was hosted via git & github.

c.desc: The post-quantum cryptography libraries were written in C.

lat.desc: Latex & overleaf were used for the documentation

sec.desc: The project was all about security.

andr.desc: The IDE used was Android Studio.

desc.s1: Right now I am doing my bachelor's degree in German in Computer Science. During my studies at this research-focused university, I have learned a plethora of valuable skills.
desc.s2: In the mandatory courses I learned all about Analysis, Linear Algebra, Stochastic, Informatics (both theoretical and practical), Computer Architecture, Networks, Distributed Systems, Databases, IT-Security and much more. The knowledge I gained in these lectures was invaluable and built the basis of my understanding of the field.
desc.s3: The last part of my studies consisted of my bachelor thesis and seminar paper. In my thesis I had to implement multiple post-quantum cryptography signature schemes within the popular open-source email client K-9 Mail in order to enable anyone to send emails, signed by algorithms that are safe from attacks from quantum computers. My seminar paper was about finding vulnerabilities in BLE.

java.desc: Java, inside and out: JSF, parallel programming and much more.

spring.desc: I used Spring Boot in the ''Web and Data Engineering'' course.

git.desc: Version control was handled with a private GitLab implementation for the university.

haskell.desc: I learned quite a bit of Haskell during the theoretical informatics courses.

c.desc: I learned some C during the theoretical informatics courses.

r.desc: I learned some R during a lecture about the language.

db.desc: I learned quite a bit of PostgreSQL in multiple courses about databases.

net.desc: I learned quite a bit of computer networks in courses like ''Distributed Systems'' and ''Networks''.

lat.desc: All research, documentations and homework were written with LaTeX.

sec.desc: I learned a lot of Cybersecurity during lectures, my bachelor thesis and my seminar work about BLE vulnerabilities.

andr.desc: For my thesis I had to modify an open-source email client on Android and I used Android Studio.

desc.s1: During the winter semester in 2021/2022 I did my mandatory internship in the University of Passau. It lasted 8 months in which a team of 5 people was mentored daily by a professor. We had to make a web application with Java, regarding scientific peer review. In this internship all five stages of development were achieved: creation of a functional specification document, design, specification, implementation and validation. An internship in the university makes one gain not only in software development and administration, but also in the scopes of time management, team building agile development and communication. Focus is given also on quality of code, efficiency and proper, secure implementation. During the internship I gained valuable skills such as: teamwork, agile development, full-stack web development, presentation skills, writing skills and more. The languages we used were Java, PostgreSQL, XML, XHTML and CSS, and some of the tools/technologies we used were IntelliJ IDEA, JSF, Primefaces, pgAdmin, TexStudio, JUnit, Selenium, REST API, etc.
desc.s2: Due to strict university policy I cannot share the repository/documents publicly, only on request.

java.desc: Java was the main language we used.

git.desc: Version control was handled with a private GitLab implementation for the university.

db.desc: For the development of the databases we used pgAdmin and PostgreSQL.

lat.desc: For all documents and presentations we used LaTeX.

desc.s1: I studied at the Bulgarian academy for software developers ''SoftUni'' for 3 years. My primary field was C# Web Developer with courses like C# Advanced, MVC, ASP.NET, and much more about databases, teamwork, entity framework, etc. I also participated in other voluntary courses like Arduino, JS Applications, Multimedia and office applications.
desc.s2: ''SoftUni'' is fundamental part of who I am now, since it is the place, where I started programming seriously.

ch.desc: I completed 6 courses for C#, as it was my field.

js.desc: I completed voluntary courses about JavaScript for front-end, back-end, applications and advanced.

java.desc: I completed two courses for Java.

vs.desc: Visual Studio was the most used IDE from me there.

desc.s1: I volunteered in a project organized by Greenpeace, that aims to assess the purity of the atmospheric air in the major cities in Bulgaria. This task was executed through an embedded system consisting of an IoT device and a web server that collected and processed the data.

chip.desc: The biggest part consisted of ATmega328P.

web.desc: We designed the web interface of the devices with HTML, CSS, JS and PHP.

proj.title: Projects, Tools and Skills I have used

pqc.title: Post-Quantum K-9 Mail
pqc.assoc: Associated with the COINS Conference & University of Passau
pqc.desc: The main project and focus for my Bachelor thesis and participation in the COINS Conference. It focuses on implementing and comparing Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) Algorithms for signing E-Mails as an Add-on for an Open Source E-mail client. The most difficult parts of the project lie in finding a way to compile a PQC library for Android and understanding and implementing the PQC algorithms within a large codebase.
pqc.tools: Kotlin, Java, SQL, Android Studio, Gradle, Selenium, JUnit, Mockito, LaTeX

pear.title: Pear Review
pear.desc: Pear Review is the biggest project I have participated in. I had to develop a Java Web Application as a system for peer review of scientific articles alongside four more people. The project was part of the mandatory internship for my degree. It ended up with more than 22,000 rows of code and more than 250 pages of documentation, planning and validation. Because the application was for the university it had to be done by the book: all security measures had to be accounted for, connection pooling, auto closing connections, tables in the database were in BCNF, redundancy, tokens, etc.
pear.tools: Jakarta Server Faces, Primefaces, Omnifaces, PostgreSQL, JUnit, Selenium, LaTeX.

gimms.title: GiiMMS
gimms.desc: A full stack employee management system for the course Web and Data Engineering.
gimms.tools: Spring Boot, Thymeleaf, JPA, IntelliJ IDEA.

kittn.title: Kittn me
kittn.desc: A full stack cat-themed social media that I did just for fun and to learn new skills.
kittn.tools: React, Redux, Firebase, Busboy, Dicer, Streamsearch.

abalone.title: AI Abalone
abalone.desc: A Java only project for the advanced course in programming. It consists of the game Abalone with GUI, so that it is possible to play against the computer in different levels of difficulty. The project is done only with math and the min-max algorithm.
